text.p: Following is a brief chronology of relations between Beijing and Moscow since the communists came to power in China in 1949.
October 2, 1949 - Soviet Union recognises Chinese People's Republic just one day after it is proclaimed in Beijing.

February 15, 1950 - Soviet Union and China sign a Treaty on Friendship, Union And Mutual Assistance, the programme document of their strong alliance. Russia takes part in more than 160 industrial projects in China.
1950-1953 - Moscow and Beijing help communist North Korea in its war with South Korea.
Early 1960s - Bilateral ties weaken and grind to a halt as two countries vie for supremacy in the communist world.
1969 - Border clashes between Soviet and Chinese troops, marking the nadir in bilateral relations.
Late 1982 - Two countries restart dialogue on normalisation of ties.
May 1989 - Soviet president Mikhail Gorbachev visits China, agrees with Beijing's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping on full normalisation of relations.
May 1991 - Jiang Zemin visits Moscow as head of Chinese Communist party.
May 1991 - Russia and China sign agreement on demarcation of eastern sector of their border.
December 1992 - Yeltsin pays first official visit to China.
September 1994 - Two countries sign agreement on demarcation of western part of their border.
September 1994 - Jiang visits Moscow as Chinese president. Signs with Yeltsin a statement proclaiming partnership in bilateral relations, agreement on non-targeting of nuclear missiles.
May 1995 - Jiang visits Moscow to take part in celebrations of 50th anniversary of allied victory in World War Two.
April 1996 - Yeltsin visits China. Russia, China, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan sign agreement on confidence-building measures along former Soviet-Chinese border.

April 22 1997 - Jiang arrives in Moscow on state visit. He and Yeltsin are due to sign political declaration outlining joint vision of future world order. Jiang, Yeltsin and the presidents of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan will also sign treaty on reducing armed forces along their borders.
